channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Someone left the awesome job machine on again… UK remote Perl job
item.description: The client is interested in anyone with experience building web apps in Perl, using one of the major Perl frameworks. If you’re a crack-hand with Catalyst, a Mojolicious master, or a distinguished Dancer, they want you. You’ll be deploying apps your work to AWS, so experience would be handy, and the company’s big on testing, so they’d like you to know your way around Test::More.

item.title: Perl Developer and Business Owner? Remote Perl role in UK & EU
item.description: Our clients run a job search engine that has grown from two friends with an idea to a site that receives more than 10 million visits per month. They offer a fully remote Perl position for those within two hours of London’s time zone. Must have a solid understanding of Object-Oriented Perl (perks if that knowledge includes Moose), SQL/MySQL and DBIx::Class.

item.title: Senior Perl Developer with Cross-Trained Chops. UK Remote Perl Role
item.description: The best senior developers know that variety is the spice of life. Sure, you’ve got Perl chops for days, but that’s not all you can do — and that’s why our client wants to meet you. They’re looking for senior Perl developers, Node engineers, and those with mighty Python and SQL skills to lead their team.

item.title: Adventure! Senior Perl roles in Malaysia, Dubai and Malta
item.description: The last few years have been sorely lacking in adventure. When your biggest thrill is a masked-up trip to the grocery store, you know life has taken a turn for the mundane. Clever folks know that if you’re lucky, you can earn a living and have an adventure at the same time. Our international client is looking for senior Perl developers with passion, drive, and an appreciation for new experiences.

item.title: Python is the choosen languages this week for Hot Day task. Finally we ended up with clean compact solution. Thanks for your contributions.
Perl Weekly Challenge 181
item.description: Luis should be declare the master of Perl one-liner. Every week we see cool one-liner. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Alphabetical and days hotter sentences
item.description: Short and sweet, logical reasoning. Nice attempt.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 181: Sentence Order and Hot day
item.description: Once again, we got the glimpse of guest languages, not as many as we used to. Thanks for your contributions.

item.title: PWC181 - Hot Day
item.description: Clever use of split, map, sort and grep. Very brave attempt. Keep it up great work.

item.title: PWC181 - Sentence Order
item.description: Raku method chaining in action. I just love it. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge 181
item.description: Compact and elegant solutions as you would expect from James. Incredible.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge: Week 181
item.description: A well structured solutions both in Perl and Raku, specially the regex one. Thanks for sharing the knowledge with us.

item.title: Back In The Saddle
item.description: Welcome back to blogging, we missed you. Nice hack of using DATA block, very smart. Well done.

item.title: An Orderly Sentencing
item.description: Colin is back with magical regex once again. I just love it. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Hot Sentence
item.description: Raku powerfull file operations in action and make the end result so compact. Cool work as always.

item.title: These Sentences Are Getting Hot
item.description: Good use case of DBD::CSV and nice little story around it. Keep it up great work.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 181
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Sentence Order" and "Hot Day" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 182
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Max Index" and "Common Path". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: Call for Grant Proposals: September 2022 Round
Interviews with Perl Developers
item.description: I was doing a lot of cleanup work on my files and on the Perl Maven site and look what I found. Some nice memories!

item.title: Cryptopals 25 - Break "random access read/write" AES CTR
Create a Daemon in Perl with Schedule::Cron
item.description: A daemon is a program that runs in the background for an indefinite period of time. An important daemon on Unix-like operating systems is the cron scheduler that can be configured to perform tasks periodically.

item.title: Cryptopals 24 - Create the MT19937 stream cipher and break it
Release 0.7.0 of Ebirah
item.description: Ebirah is an experimental Docker project for Dist::Zilla. This release contains a minor improvement from Alceu Rodrigues de Freitas Junior.

item.title: Cryptopals 23 - Clone an MT19937 RNG from its output
Release 0.3.0 of my Perl Dist::Zilla GitHub Action
item.description: The release is long over due and the first in two years.

item.title: ANSI Colors and Perl
item.description: A response to another article on using ANSI colors in Perl.

item.title: #581 - What to write about?
item.description:
Hi there!

People often tell me that they don't know what to write about or that they are too new to Perl to blog about anything. Let's see.

Last week I posted this article about ANSI command line colors with Perl. It hardly has anything to do with Perl, but I needed it and it can be a useful to others as well. Actually it originated from a discussion I had with my son who is using Python. So first I wrote the article ANSI colors using Python and only after that I converted it to Perl.

It did not require any deep knowledge, definitely not that of Python or Perl.

So if you would like to try writing articles, there are plenty of such small subjects one can cover.

After including the link in the previous edition of the Perl Weekly, Thomas Köhler contacted me saying that he would do it differently and then he posted a short article showing how would he use ANSI colors in Perl including a link back to the original article.

This is excellent.

So here is a suggestion: If you don't have an idea for an article, pick one of the Perl Maven posts and write a different solution or extend the subject and send a link to us, the editors of the Perl Weekly.

Enjoy your week!
item.dc:subject: editorial
